title: Creating MacOS Windows Installation Media
body:
## Windows10 download

[Windows10 ISO] (https://www.microsoft.com/ja-jp/software-download/windows10iso)


Create ## Boot Media

Double -click the downloaded ISO on the above site and mount it. Then execute the script as follows.

GPT-> MBR may work.

`` `bash
$ # Media format
$ DISKUTIL ERASEDISK MS-DOS "Win10" GPT /DEV /DISK4
Transfer files other than $ # SourceS/Install.wim
$ rsync -avh --progress --Exclude = sources/install.wim/volumes/cccoma_x64fre_ja -jp_dv9//Volumes/win10
$ # SourceS/Install.wim is divided and write
$ Wimlib-IMAGEX Split/Volumes/cccoma_x64fre_ja-jp_dv9/sources/install.wim /volumes/win10/sources/install.swm 3200
$ # /dev /DISK4 mounting
$ Diskutil Unmountdisk /Dev /Disk4
`` `

* Change `/Dev/DISK4` to the corresponding external USB media directory. (You can check the current connected disk information with `$ diskutil list`.)
* If Wimlib is not installed, execute and install `$ BREW INSTALL WIMLIB`.

After execution, it is the same as the normal Windows installation procedure.

## Funning

I remembered that it was easy to make with the DD command, but when did it become so complicated?

It seems that `Install.wim` has exceeded 4GB and exceeds the upper limit (4GB) of FAT32.

The SWM extension knew for the first time that it seems to be used to split the WIM file.
